Comment: Where in the Gospels did Jesus anoint the Twelve to be priests?  No place.  What Jesus DID DO at the Last Supper, was get on his knees and wash their feet.  He told them to do so for others as he had done.  Jesus was of the Tribe of Judah and the House of David.  He was not a Levite nor of the House of Aaron.  Jesus called himself the Good Shepherd, the Way, the Truth and the Life.  He permitted himself to be called Rabbi/Teacher.  But he never called himself a Priest.  Nor did he ordain his followers as such.

If one studies early Church history---one sees that the people elected/chose their bishops, their popes, and their presbyters for the liturgy.  This lasted until just after the Edict of Milan in 311 AD.  When the church became acceptable to the Roman emperor [Constantine] and a state religion, the liturgy was moved out of the home, into a church---and a clergy [male] was developed.

Comment: Our Constitution requires the President to be a natural born citizen of the United States, but provides no specifics about how this is to be proven, thus leaving the matter to each state to decide. Each state's Secretary of State must follow that state's laws, if any, to make a reasonable determination that a candidate for President meets this requirement before placing them on the ballot. This must not be a politically motivated determination, but a factually determined one. The press and citizens play a part in bringing to light any factual concerns, and this was reasonably the case for Mr. Obama as he had provided only a short form birth certificate in 2008. In 2011 Mr. Trump called for the long form to be submitted. Three weeks later, Mr. Obama released the long form. Mr. Trump is not a "birther" but has been a reasonable skeptic, and has now laid the matter to rest. Those who continue to criticize him for his concern do so out of naked political motivation.

"cide" = "to kill".

Comment: It always sounds so little - just a few cents per $1,000 levy, but all the levies the city and county have burdened the property owners with add up. These programs that continue to burden only property owners are unfair since not everyone that might benefit from these programs are property owners.

In Canada issues that tax property owners or not are voted by property owners - not the general population. That seems more fair since obviously non-property owners don't care - they don't have to sent a check to the tax assessor's office.

Another point - not all property owners are the same. Some might have to have multiple wage owners, some might be more financially strapped - such as elderly on fixed incomes.

I submit "the common good of our community" should be to stop trying to take the community's money for every fuzzy-feeling program that comes along. To me it says you hate your community and you don't care about the financial impact of accumulated taxes.

Comment: Traditional schools have failed to improve educational outcomes as much as they could based on what we know.  That failure comes from many sources including lack of knowledge on methods, reluctance to change from many groups, and structural problems imposed by state and federal funding.
Charter school sometimes produce improved results for some students some of the time. They seldom fulfill their original stated purpose which was to improve instructional methods for all children. Supporting charter schools is a vote to for short term gains for some students some of the time but distracts from the larger problem of progress for all students which requires structural change with appropriate materials and methods.
The changes will likely involve less reliance on the old age based grade level with one teacher per grade class with a strong emphasis on the ability to adapt instruction on more individualized methods.

Comment: Petty harassment is what accomplished this?  I guess I must be a Pollyanna, then  --  I'd been thinking it was a belated recognition of the only vote our City government has allowed on the issue of water fluoridation.  

Our local "anti" groups have been trying for years simply to get the right to put this question to a popular vote.  The City has been refusing for years  --  even to the point of being sued for the right to put the issue on the ballot.  

The best outcome to Mayor Downey's belated change of heart is that we finally get to let the people of PA decide whether they want their water to be fluoridated.  

The vote we will finally get to have in 2017 is the vote we should have been allowed to have in 2006, when the Council of that time unilaterally decided to sign a fool's contract, ten years long and with a huge cancellation penalty, with no input at all from their constituents.

Comment: Just feel good mummery.

There's still 2.5 male entrepreneurs for every female entrepreneur in small business, and that ratio just gets worse the larger the corporation is, with medium businesses running 6:1 and large businesses running 13:1. Female entrepreneurs start smaller, more service oriented businesses that aren't particularly profitable, see more attrition compared to their male peers, and poorer 10 year survivability rates for their businesses.

30 years or more of female only VC, female only business associations, female preferred lending rates, SB programs for women at every financial institution in the country, all sorts of government grant programs, entire government agencies like SOW devoted to the cause ... and engagement is still the number one issue, decades later.

Who cares if women benefit more from entrepreneurship programs when the single biggest issue facing women in business is still their own lack of willingness to start the process?

Comment: It's true that there is an insufficient supply of technology talent in Canada, but that is also true in the US. Anywhere they go is going to have this problem.

In fact, if I may join in the speculation for a moment, I feel like the only reason Amazon would seriously consider Canada as a candidate for HQ2 would be immigration policy. The US caps the number of H-1B visas it issues each year, and there is a threat that the current government might make it even harder to get them. In Canada it is easier to bring someone in as a TFW, and the government has lately been making it more appealing by removing time restrictions on the visas.

Comment: I see a number of people asking whether a gun can be drawn and employed if the perp is just a few feet away with a knife. Just a couple of quick comments... 

1.  Separate! Move, step aside and/or back, get yourself out of the perp's immediate reach.
2.  While moving, draw your weapon. Do not "show it to him", do not issue a warning... put the front sight on the center of mass and pull the trigger.  Repeat as necessary.  If the perp is too close to use the sights, don't worry...  at 6 feet, you won't need them anyway. Instinctive pointing works well at that range... 

Remember, the element of surprise works both ways. Typically, a thug with a knife won't be expecting you to be carrying a gun... if he did, he probably would not have chosen you as his target. He will be surprised to see the gun in your hand, and it will take him a second or two to process that... enough time for you to score a couple of solid hits, if you've trained as you should for concealed carry.

Comment: Aloha Narissa,

I am sure you mean well.  However, please understand that expanding the monument is not as simple as has been presented by its advocates, and it will significantly affect local people.  Especially small-scale fishermen on Kauai who depend on the area for bottomfish and ahi. This could potentially destroy some peoples' livelihoods, including Hawaiians.  Nor is the science a "no-brainer".  There is a long history of management and data collection within the US EEZ by NOAA.  Much of this does not support the idea that closing the entire area to Hawaii-based fishing vessels will serve the interests of conservation.  As a fisherman I firmly believe that our future lies in science-based management, not arbitrary ocean closures.

This is a complex issue, and I would encourage you to take the time to speak with and listen to those who will be affected by the President's decision before endorsing this proposal wholeheartedly.  Is this something you'd be interested in doing?

The problem with hockey analytics is twofold.  1st, the #s don't tell you anything you could not just as easily ascertain by just watching the game(s); and 2nd, it's been shown statistically that around 75% of determining which team is going to win boils down to goaltending and luck.

The cost of the actual camera is rather small, it's the storage of the cameras(they have to be docked to charge), staff to manage the cameras and the footage, and then the cost of the data which is required in most places to be kept a minimum of 30 days.  This can cost small departments tens of thousands of dollars a year and for large departments like Denver or Aurora the cost could easily be in the hundreds of thousands maybe more.

Comment: Personal politics aside, I've been concerned for a while about the overly harsh regulations against aquaculture on Federal Refuge lands. State law dictates that salmon enhancement projects practice due diligence to preserve genetic diversity whenever they do a project, but I've seen a few ultimately beneficial projects get shut down on the Kenai peninsula because the air traffic during stocking might negatively affect the wildlife. I'm pretty sure Kodiak Island has gone through some equally unjustified restrictions on projects designed to benefit Alaskans, be they commercial, subsistence, or sport users, solely based on decisions by Refuge Managers that control 60%+ of the island but admittedly don't have fishery resources in mind. Kodiak might be a unique example because it's a Kodiak Bear Refuge, but regardless of how I feel about the current commander in chief, I think the rest of the state would benefit from having a discussion about how the Refuges manage the surrounding waters.

I love the Denali and Richardson highways and enjoy this hunt, but am dumbfounded about the amount of reckless and unethical actions that are performed while hunting this unit. Last year, watched a group take a dozen pot-shots at a small bull, cow and calf/yearling. We watched them hit all three from what appeared to be 600+ yards, then the animals ran off out of sight. Well the group returned to camp late that night with one animal, and when questioned said "we missed the others there was no blood trail". SMH

Comment: Yup, I'm one. An adult, I mean.  And yeah, I had trouble. 
I got 3 correct answers. And one of those was a guess.  
I learned more (useful, practical) math after I was 30 years old than at any time previous.  Because the incentive was there: I now had my own company and had to make a profit or I wouldn't be able to feed, clothe and house myself.  It was that simple. I had a lot of computation practice...learned to crunch numbers really well; every invoice I mailed was full of 'em and sometimes spent hours making them accurate (not just for me but a host of suppliers and contractors I put to work.)  Learned to estimate extremely well, too. Learned where my true financial worth lay, so I didn't waste time/energy. I paid myself my first salary 2 weeks after I began operations, and  operated the company profitably for 20 years.

But I'd probably be in the 50% failure group.  

And so, the moral of the story is...

"Needs must."

Comment: Here's two unproven claims. Obama: the Russians hacked the US electoral process. Trump: 3 million illegal ballots by immigrants cost me the popular vote. Despite the fact that not a shred of proof of either claim has been offered, many people accept the former as gospel while scoffing at the latter. But is Trump's claim truly incredible?

There are approximately 11 million immigrants  in the US illegally today. There are a further 22 million lawful immigrants in the US who are not yet qualified to vote. That totals 33 million immigrants who, if they voted, did so illegally. Trump is claiming that perhaps 1 in 10 of those immigrants managed to vote against him, due to his tough stand on immigration, etc.

If you're willing to believe- without any proof- that the Russians hacked the US electoral process, then why would you refuse to believe that a small percentage of US immigrants managed to cast an illegal ballot?

Comment: Your statements are ignorant in both anthropology and zoology.  
In Anthropology
Prior to agrarian systems (10,000 years ago) humans lived in nomadic groups for 1oo's of thousands of years and worked cooperatively to provide for each other, the groups were voluntary  associations.  Food was shared with the whole community, even if  the hunter got the beast, he shared with all.  It was not a constant state of war, nor do animals live in a constant state of war.  

The fight or flight response (stress response was designed for minutes and hours), not, months, and  years of stress.  Please  read some recent books anthropology and biology, before stating natures principles.  (Recent because science is constantly improving our understanding)

The economic system, capitalism, we have today based on resource ownership and rents is not natural and is a recent development of the last 200 years, it does not characterize how humans cared for each other during most of our evolution.

Comment: The ACA was very similar to the bill that Mitt Romney (R) passed in MA while he was governor there.  It was not far to the left - that would have been legislation that opted for a medicaid for all type of bill.  Rather, it was a bill that the Republicans would have loved had Romney or McCain been elected.  It gave a lot of leeway to insurance companies, whose goal is to keep premiums as high as sustainable while denying as much coverage as possible.  This is the market at work.  The unfortunate part of that plan is that humans, and their health, are the widgets.
Eventually this will be clear, but it will probably take a generation or two for society to see through all the obfuscation.  In the meantime, we will just have a lot of infighting while insurance companies and their shareholders get rich.  Sadly, a lot of people will go bankrupt trying to pay for their or their children's illnesses.  It's already happening, right here in the richest country the world has ever known.

Comment: I was expecting something more restrictive from the committee, so I'm pleasantly surprised that they delivered a more moderate set of recommendations. For example, I'm glad that they didn't follow the CMA's recommendation to set the minimum age at 25, which would've forced all young adults outside the legal market. However, the plain packaging requirement is unwise, and works against their goal to allow "craft" products, as plain packaging makes it difficult for new products to gain market share by outlawing branding and advertising.

And as always, the door has been left open for provinces to muck this up, and there's always the possibility the government could ignore the committee's report and implement something dumber.

Comment: I mostly agree, Lynn. I thought my assessment was coldly rational, and what I advocated is multilateral negotiation. My only purpose was to lay out the special interests, and emphasize that very powerful forces are behind that - maybe unstoppable forces.  Perhaps you didn't notice, but I did not characterize the US as a "good guy", in fact I made a blanket statement that there are no "good guys" in the Syrian battleground.  I think my summation gave at least an idea of the complex situation, at least I hope so, because that was my goal.  I am past fighting battles, Lynn.  I want rationality, and I always strive to provide it.

If you or anyone can find a way to extricate the US from Middle East conflicts without, at this point, "pouring gasoline" on an already blazing fire, you deserve a Nobel Peace Prize.  What I am interested in is the why and wherefore of human conflict, in search of a palliative or resolution.

Thank you for your kind response.

Comment: Fair comment, NickyB. There is no reason to believe a list of historical droughts from 2003 would be invalid today (albeit that two droughts need to be added, as I did).

But I stand by my point. Science might get overturned or supplanted by new and improved science, but it does not expire on its own. Einstein's theories are a century old and nobody is dismissing them for their age. Even Newton's far older laws remain valid approximations at low speed and mass. Ditto Euclid, Kepler, Euler, Curie, Maxwell, Pascal, Darwin and many other great scientists of the past. We do not dismiss their work simply because it is old, and much of it remains in daily use by scientists today.

Comment: There is no post-glacial evidence of bear or cougars in the islands (wolves are well documented), and there is extensive ethnographic and archeological evidence of people (Coast Salish) hunting deer for thousands of years prior to European colonization. It is an all too common mistake in the biological community to treat human interaction and impacts on wildlife as a modern phenomenon, despite rich evidence to the contrary. In the islands humans have probably been the primary predators of deer for the majority of the post-glacial period, and putting people back into our models, as we do at Kwiaht by studying historical ecology, will better inform our understanding of post-Contact ecosystems and help us make better decisions about their restoration and management.

Comment: The West doesn't have the best farmland in Canada. The most productive farmland in Canada is in SW Ontario, particularly along the shore of Lake Erie. It has a much longer growing season (where I live is just slightly north of the 44th parallel, which is the California/Oregon state line), reliable rainfall, an inexhaustible water supply (the Great Lakes) and rich soil, much richer than in the West due to the soil the glaciers scraped off the Canadian Shield to the north. This is why farmland in Ontario is valued at some 10x that of the Prairies and the best farmland in SW Ontario, like in Chatham-Kent where I live, is sold for 20x what an acre on the Prairies is sold for.

Comment: PHILCO, if the company says they are going to pay 50% less, you have a choice to make.  One is that you try to negotiate less of a cut.  Another is you refuse and strike.   The down side is that the job may move (as it did in this case).  Another option is to take the amount being offered.

I agree that people have families to feed, and I feel sorry for anyone who is facing a slash in their income.  And I did answer you....I said I don't know.  I wouldn't know what I would do when and if I faced such a decision. 

Sure, I would protest, but in any negotiation situation you have to realize when you cannot win.  When that happens, you either take less than what you want, or your risk losing much more.  

Some people can afford to strike and risk losing everything with the prospect of getting more.  Some cannot.

I'm not saying this is a great situation, but I'm a realist.  Any good business owner considers the bottom line, and you would too.

Comment: As some have posted, probably scud-running under VFR. With the near- total destruction of the aircraft, we'll probably never definitively know exactly what went wrong. But the ADS-B data should show their altitude and track, and we'll know if they filed IFR or not. If they were on an IFR plan, they were way off in altitude, which usually requires at least a 2000' clearance from the highest terrain in the vicinity. If they had an emergency at altitude, they should have had time to at least issue a mayday. But from the photo and reports from the site, it looks as though they flew straight into the mountain at cruise speed.

I had enough experiences with Hageland - many of which a non-pilot would not have been aware - that I really, really tried to avoid them. That said, all the air taxis have their cowboys. Comment: I've seen Moose with calves in the marsh area on the west side of RMNP.  And people going ito it to get closer for a pic. Way too close. Those long legs are made for getting through brush, and a person 100 feet away from a moose isn't getting away fast enough. The moose wouldn't exert much energy getting there. It's dangerous to approach moose with calves.

Near Walden last summer I saw a moose running along a cattle fence by the highway and suddenly turn and hurdle the fence before running across the highway to effortlessly hurdle another 5 foot cattle fence and make it to a grazing area.

CDOW doesn't know if they were native to Colorado or not. It seems highly likely they were in remote areas of northwest Colorado before re-introduction. Horses aren't native to this country, for comparison's sake. My advice to people... give space to moose and don't get too close. A bull male is capable of fighting off bears and wolves.

Comment: #2
The ambo was in the middle of the nave and elevated so the human voice (singing and reading) could be heard by all without electronic amplification. The Liturgy of the Word was entirely centred around the ambo, with the people, standing, facing it from all directions. 

The Little Entrance was a procession from the sanctuary with the Gospel Book to the ambo. For the Eucharistic Liturgy, the people move towards and faced the altar in the middle of the sanctuary. The purpose of this low barrier was, obviously, to demarcate the area of the people and prevent crowding into the area reserved for the Eucharistic action. 

The Great Entrance was a procession from the back vestibule where the deacons, prior to the public liturgy, had collected the bread and wine brought by the people and selected what was required for the Eucharist. This procession, having gone around the ambo, followed the runway from the ambo to the sanctuary.

Comment: "Research shows that... those that have quotas like them, and those that do not, fear them".

What utter nonsense.

That sentence is trying to pretend the following:

1. When people oppose quotas, it stems from an emotional fear of quotas.
2. Whenever quotas are implemented by new laws, people lose their emotional fear of quotas and subsequently they like quotas.

Who on Earth is the writer trying to kid?

Plenty of people oppose quotas for reasons that have nothing to do with fear, but rather have to do with viewpoints of fairness and ethics and justice.

And you can bet that in places where quotas were implemented by new laws, plenty of people remained opposed to them for the reasons (not emotions!) mentioned in my previous sentence. Which is to say that people are diverse, already! People are not little emotional cartoon stereotypes.

It is bizarre that a piece proclaiming itself to champion diversity is so blind to diversity in its own stated words...

Comment: Building a theatre sounds like a southern solution to a northern problem. You might best place it in Iqualuit, the capital of Nunavut, which has a population of around 8000--not really enough to support all that much of a theatre scene. The rest of Nunavut's 35,000 or so citizens are spread out in small settlements over an area the size of Western Europe and mostly unconnected to each other by road--a still small number of people most of whom are unlikely ever to have access to a theatre that tries to represent them in Iqualuit. Someone needs to come up with a way of bringing theatre and other arts to this deserving population without assuming it requires the kind of buildings we create here in the south?

Comment: Well, let's consider what the law presumably protects here. No one is arguing for an established religion, and no one is preventing Mr. Philips from practicing his religion or attending worship services. Those are public expressions of one's religious faith, protected under the law. 
Now Mr. Philips claims that baking a cake (or not) is also a public expression of his protected religious faith. If most, or at least, many members of his religion were bakers, that might be true. But this is a private individual privately interpreting the law and claiming that the state must protect his private interpretation of the law. At that point, I think the legal system has to decide, not what he can believe, but whether he is privately interpreting the law in a discriminatory manner. I think....

Comment: Personal experience, discussion with other transit riders, and common sense.  

For instance, fares have gone up many times over the years at RTD, yet ridership overall keeps going up and up.  Sure, you'll lose a few people just about anytime you raise prices (for just about anything), but most that leave for that reason are likely to come back for the very reason they took transit in the first place -- because it was a good fit for their situation.  Otherwise they wouldn't have been using it to begin with.

From a cost standpoint alone, such highly subsidized transit fares are way cheaper than owning and operating a private vehicle.  That would still be true even if you doubled the fares (not that I'm proposing they be doubled, but the point would still remain even if you did).

Comment: Large-scale attacks on Canada are vulnerable to discovery and prevention by the normal methods. The only kind of attack that can squeeze through that safety net is of the independent, 'lone-wolf' variety. On the scale of threats to their well-being that Canadians blandly face every day, the threat of a lone-wolf terrorist is insignificant. 

Bulk data collection is about getting that lone-wolf terrorist, about finding the needle in the haystack. The price that we pay for ameliorating that insignificant threat is mass surveillance of the entire population. 
Having a turn-key totalitarian state waiting in the wings is not the answer to the minimal threat that bulk data collection can only hope to prevent.

Comment: Of course, there is room for development of the church's sexual ethics. The Eastern Orthodox church has never taught that procreation is the purpose or end of marriage, and its attitude to divorce is practical and merciful. The Roman's church's sexual ethics have been shaped by a kind of harshness that does not even serve its own ends. I would invite anyone to demonstrate, for example, how "the widest possible space is [to be] open to women in all areas of culture, economics, politics and ecclesial life itself" without the reality of lifelong virginity or comprehensive fertility management. On the subject of same-sex relationships, a good start would be to stop silencing the theologians--something that is done almost exclusively in the Roman church. Surely avoiding the appearance of scandal has been revealed for what it is--nothing but a power play. Or perhaps it should be asked: does the Roman church even respect the notion of dialogue?

Comment: Will these be mobile/manufactured homes or modular homes? They are not the same thing. 

Modular homes look similar to stick-built homes but are built in sections inside a climate-controlled factory. Modular homes arrive in sections on flatbed trucks and are then set in place onsite and finished.

Mobile homes (aka manufactured) are single- or doublewide trailers mounted on wheels and less sturdily constructed. 

This mislabeling perpetuates the notion that modular homes are inferior, when in fact they meet modern building standards and are usually very energy efficient. Modular homes have the added advantage of being built indoors instead of exposed to the elements and vulnerable to rain and mold.

Comment: Pedestrian crossings are difficult even if drivers obey the law. Pedestrians are begrudgingly granted a brief sliver of traffic time and pressured by cars wanting to turn. We need to give pedestrians more time and time that is exclusively theirs, not shared with turning cars. 
At a six-lane-with-median street near me, pedestrians must push a button to request crossing. It can take up to three minutes for the lights to change and then the Walk signal appears for only about 5 seconds. Don't let yourself be distracted or you could miss it! Legally you can begin crossing only when the light says Walk, not during the countdown that follows. I'm still healthy and can make the crossing with 10 seconds or more to spare. But there might not be enough time for a frail senior with a walker.

Comment: "With the horror of the Marco Polo fire top of mind, it’s hard to imagine that there are people who want very much to be the ones charging into danger and risking their lives to save strangers."

Lee, is that what the firefighters did at Marco Polo?  I saw most outside unable to enter the building because they "did not have the proper equipment", according to the HFD spokesperson.  The question shouldn't be if we need sprinklers to make it safer for firefighters but why didn't HFD have the proper equipment to respond to a high-rise fire with so many condos under development.

Let's get one thing straight: people likely died because of the inadequate fire alarm and lack of an evacuation plan, not the absence of sprinklers.  Sprinklers mitigate property damage and control the fire until the firefighters can respond.  Sprinklers are not designed to extinguish fires, unless halon is the extinguishing agent.  Sprinklers also do not prevent smoke, which is likely what killed the individuals.

Comment: The most dynamic part of capitalism is supply and demand. There is not much demand for underwater basket weavers - what reward/handout/minimum income should underwater basket weavers receive when there is no demand? In 1999 there was a LOT of demand for Y2K programmers - when supply of y2k programmers got low - the wage people were willing to pay went up.  When hurricane katrina destroyed LA - food, water and gasoline was in scarce supply - those who demanded the products had to pay more - some people called it gouging - some people called it absolutely necessary to prevent hoarding.

That really is the underlying problem in our country - we are based on capitalism - we didn't become the biggest economy and producer in the world through any other mechanism - Yet we are on the threshold of a possible dramatic change in the country. Which path we walk down next will have dramatic effects - some for the greater good - some perhaps not.

Comment: On reading this article I cannot help but reflect on the policies proposed by the US president-elect.

He is proposing punishing companies for moving to new low-wage jurisdictions, by putting up trade barriers to prevent them from selling in America.

The market distortions resulting from limiting the economic freedom of firms in a global economy are staggering. It can only result in lower wages, higher unemployment, inflation, and a huge wealth transfer from US consumers to corporations. In addition to that, it will seriously constrain the number of small-business startups, and choke off the positive spillover effects they bring to society.

It is absolutely amazing that in the first place, such a policy could be considered, and in the second, that it would find public support. But bad policies have bad outcomes...unless you're a wealthy businessman, in which case it makes you wealthier. And who did Trump line up as his closest advisers in cabinet? Hmmm.

Comment: There are a number of studies that indicate that stocks with material insider buying tend to outperform the market over the next 12 months, e.g. work done by Nejat Seyhun, a prof at the University of Michigan.

To a lesser extent data suggests that the reverse is true for insider selling. 

Personally, I believe that insider buying is a more meaningful indicator than insider selling since the latter is often driven by insiders exercising stock options because their expiry date is looming.

Comment: I like Tory but no taxes of any kind are needed.  Let the free market sort things out as it always does.  And if the market is indeed getting ahead of itself, well position yourself accordingly and you can profit from such an opportunity.  Until then renting is always an option or moving further away from the core into one of the many rapidly gentrifying neighborhoods or suburbs in the GTA.

And as to the sources of the demand I say bring on all that foreign capital from our sources.  We need it in Canada, badly.  Wealthy Asian buyers are a very positive force in this country.  Immigration of all kinds is needed to sustain our economy.  

The best thing that the government can do to ease the housing situation is to accelerate the development of new housing, particularly new rental housing.  That is the most equitable and effective way to ensure more Canadian residents can find housing.  More taxes are not the answer.  They are never the answer.

Comment: "The president aligned his agenda with that of Jackson. 'He understood real leadership means putting America first.'"

Mike Huckabee, a Baptist minister, urged Trump to follow Jackson's example with respect to the Supreme Court case of Worcester v. Georgia, 31 U.S. 515 (1832). The court said that laws forcing Native Americans off their lands were unconstitutional. Jackson is supposed to have said, "John Marshall has made his decision; now let him enforce it!" Whether or not Jackson did say that, it defines his attitude.

Jackson's support of the unconstitutional Indian Removal Act led directly to one of the most shameful episodes in US history, the Trail of Tears. Huckabee is not only urging Trump to act unconstitutionally, but also apparently supports the Trail of Tears. Neither one is what a Christian minister and former governor should do.

Comment: If you want to ask about corruption, the most blatant piece of corruption in the past several years was in the town of Cicero. 

Betty Loren-Maltese used to be the Town President of Cicero. She inherited the job from her husband, Frank Maltese, who had to resign after he was convicted of mob-related gambling charges. Loren-Maltese got into trouble when a reporter discovered she had bought a house in Las Vegas for $1 million, yet her salary was $85K. So where did the money come from? 

The U.S. Attorney started looking into Cicero, and discovered that Loren-Maltese, the Town Treasurer, the Town Attorney, the Police Chief and his predecessor, and a couple of mafiosi had robbed the town of $12 million.

The replacement as Cicero Town Attorney, Edward "Fast Eddie" Vrdolyak, a former Chicago Alderman, was convicted of fraud. His successor was shown to have overbilled the town, but paid the money back and no charges were filed.

Comment: The trap I constantly see observers falling into is attempting to assess Trump's strategic thinking in various circumstances.  There is one possibility that often goes overlooked: He doesn't have one.  The hazards of inaccurately projecting meaning onto his behavior has three obvious dangers: 

One is that there is a tendency to cut him some critical slack when his actions are perceived as the product of deliberate & careful thought.

The second is that once meaning is projected onto his actions, then that gets ensconced as truth and used for further deeper & even more inaccurate interpretations.

Finally, the third is that it blinds analysts to the possibility that Trump's inscrutable methods are actually as idiotic as they seem at first glance.

Comment: Although I'm a resident I still disagree with your premise that out of staters are consumers of state services, at least to a significant degree. Most your examples would be unlikely to be utilized by the out of state worker in question, especially at levels approaching residents. And the primary funding source for most the services you mention are either local governments or the federal government. He also surely pays federal taxes which flow back here. He also pays federal and state gas taxes. If he stays in a hotel or rental or even housing provided by his employer he is paying something through property taxes or bed taxes. So if you want to argue he is an incidental and insignificant consumer of state services that should pay "something" I'll buy that, but I'll argue that through his existing contributions he is probably already covering the cost. Along your argument I should pay income tax to Oregon when I visit family there because I "might" need state services there.

Comment: More false claims from James.

1.  The only dental fluorosis which may be attributable to fluoridated water is mild to very mild, a barely detectable effect which causes no adversity on cosmetics, form, function, or health of teeth.  This level of dental fluorosis is neither "enamel damage" nor does it require any treatment whatsoever.

2.  The "41% of all children" is a complete misrepresentation of a 2010 CDC study by Beltran-Aguilar in which 41% of adolescents examined showed signs of dental fluorosis.  This consisted of 37.1% with mild dental fluorosis, 3.8% moderate, and negligible severe, with the moderate being attributable  to improper ingestion of toothpaste, and/or exposure to high levels of environmental or well-water fluoride during teeth developing years of 0-8.

As can be seen, James provides yet further example of the dishonesty which is rife amongst antifluoridationists.

Steven D. Slott, DDS

Comment: I have mixed feelings about the KITV project.
On one hand, it's always best to keep journalists at arm's length from a newspaper's or TV station's advertisers. That's basic stuff.
On the other, back in the late 80s or early 90s, KGMB took me and my wife along on a Caribbean cruise it had awarded to some key advertisers. Somebody had cancelled and I guess the station manager felt I deserved some reward for extra duties I'd taken on at the station. There was no advertising about the trip or my presence. I did not speaking or socializing I didn't want. In fact, I got to know a PR/Advertising person who later was able to help me as a source nail down a difficult story.
I think the issue mainly becomes one of public perception -- like so many things for journalists and lawmakers. Outsiders might perceive too much chumminess, although no one who knows Paula Akana would believe she was "dress up" a bad story because she met one of the involved people on a cruise!

Comment: Trolls have been around for as long as I can remember (ca. 1993) when, as a comp newbie, I found out about CompuServe and .soc groups.
Some of them very obnoxious, with very "clever" handles. Rather than argue it was best to tackle them with different means. 
Two of them — who worked in tandem — got treated to a fairy tale in installments, basically their stupid replies served as the basis for the next installment with "that special twist". I found it great fun, it worked very well. They were the almost daily joke of that .soc group and left prior to my final installment, but we sure didn't miss them. 
And what was the tale about? Location changed between Trollhättan, Sweden and Switzerland. It was all about the two "clowns" having great difficulty finding their way around Zürich, looking for the  infamous "Gnomes of Zürich". ;)

Comment: Hamish,
Your tarantula is not a service animal unless it can demonstrate that is can perform a specific service that is needed for daily life and a licensed physician has written a letter detailing that it is trained and needed to help due to a physical disability.
Your tarantula can be a emotional support animal (ESA) if you have a letter from a licensed physician or psychiatrist that it provides you with emotional support. But, that does not give you the legal right to take it everywhere, only places where ESA's are allowed by law (certain housing) or if it is an airline and you meet their requirements for a ESA.
AAT animals are animals who have training to provide "comfort", usually dogs and cats, and they have a owner or handler who brings them to hospitals, senior centers, or where ever the person or people are who need comfort. The dogs or cats are trained to be petted, held and do not remain there. Most recently, AAT dogs were used to comfort kids in shelters after the hurricane

Comment: i  grew up in the heart of Appalachia in Floyd County KY.  (My home town of Drift was the centerfold in Time magazine in the years of the war on poverty.) It would be better to ask who is lifted up by fine art which enhances community worship.  Bishop Maes truly believed that the poor have as  much right to beauty as the rich and so did Bishop Mulloy who did a major renovation near the 50th anniversary of the Cathedral. He incorporated 1/4 sawn  Appalachian oak in the sanctuary, carved ambo and baldichino.  At that time our diocese included all of Appalachian kentucky.  
There is absolutely no comparison to the vulgar and tasteless displays of Trump.

Comment: (continued re "faith"): By presenting that "faith" is associated with hope and goodness, this implies the polar opposite - (that non-belief is desolate and bad). Of course this is erroneous - but believers easily fall into this trap. 

Politicians regularly use the same trick: "We are the party of jobs/transparency/help" - (and the other is the party of no jobs/hidden agendas/no help). Meta-communications silently guide us into limited (and probably erroneous) beliefs. "Faith is goodness" is such a trap. The word "faith" becomes a sacred cow which few question. We should.

Humans are basically quite gullible and easily get miss-directed in these ways. It is work to search for our own blind-spots and to counteract our own gullibilities. Religions count on you NOT doing that. 

Beliefs not accompanied by evidence are worthy of being scrutinized and perhaps challenged. Enjoy them personally like you enjoy ice cream. But be suspicious of their effect if slipped into government meetings.

Comment: I know the specifics of these situations vary, but one thing they each seem to have in common is that the shooter wants to make some sort of "statement." If we deny them the platform to do that, we might cut down on the motivations for these episodes.

There was an excellent article by Ari Schulman in the Wall Street Journal in November, 2013 about the phenomenon of the lone wolf mass killer and how to stop them, and this was his premise. We need to stop focusing so much attention on the perpetrators and, instead, place the focus on the victims, where it belongs.

In part, I blame the 24-hour news beast for this phenomenon. They plaster these killers' pictures on the screen and on the cover of People magazine and then drone on incessantly about who he was and why he did it. But we know that one reason he did it was precisely because he knew it would get that kind of attention. 

And you can bet that the next monster-in-waiting is taking it all in.

Comment: Lester Pearson supported Canada's acceptance of nuclear armed Bomarc missiles, which Diefenbaker, after some dithering,  rejected.  That's why Kennedy supported Pearson and opposed Diefenbaker. Neither Kennedy  nor Nixon-Kissinger were responding to peace marches in their first steps toward detente. Also,  few people in the 1950s or 1960s thought that hiding under desks would make a difference in the case of nuclear attack, apart from flying objects, or, for that matter, that the bomb shelters  some people were building were likely to make much difference.  Thinking about nuclear war simply produced fear, dread and nausea that could be relieved only by putting the thought out of one's mind and getting on with life ---marriage, school, children, home, ice hockey, reading the funny pages, or whatever---however absurd that might be in the end,  since there was little that one could do about it anyway. What one could do is vote for relatively sane people.

Comment: How will making housing harder to buy for ordinary Canadians ease the housing crunch? 

If you have fewer people able to afford a house due to higher mortgage qualifications, there will be fewer units sold, therefore builders will stop building as demand dwindles.  Less supply ultimately equals higher prices, but only being paid by the few who meet the new threshold.  

And the newly disqualified would-be buyers don't evaporate.  They fulfill their housing needs by renting; exacerbating the rental shortage and driving rents higher.

The current rate of mortgage arrears in Canada is 0.28% - this is fixing a problem we don't have.  But if you want to further divide the country in housing-haves, and housing-havenots, this is the way to do it.

For Toronto and Vancouver, limit foreign buyers.  Make it easier to build more and more units.  Make it easier for qualified Canadians to own their own homes.  A couple thousand empty units begging for buyers will bring prices down.

Comment: I do not agree that Dr. Marrus' comment was "stupid," "hurtful" and "racial." That is an unfair characterization of the words he spoke.

I interpret Dr. Marrus' words as wry humour, most likely at the expense of Hugh Segal, the Master of Massey College. Far from being stupid, the humour illuminates the anachronistic use of the term "Master" at the U of T. As for the comment being intrinsically hurtful, it's clear that it's not. The black student and Hugh Segal CHOSE to be hurt by the humour, but they could've just as readily brushed it off. It clearly wasn't a comment intended to impugn them personally.

Finally, the editor asserts that Dr. Marrus' comment was "racial," as in racist. That's absurd. A racist comment is one that proposes, supports or evinces racist views. That the words spoken may have had a racial theme in no way means that they were racist.

Dr. Marrus is essentially blameless in this affair. Hugh Segal and Massey College are not.

If the article is talking about a couple hundred fuel cell cars, probably no affect.  If all the cars in Honolulu are swapped for fuel cell vehicles, well, perhaps it will matter.  Which brings us back to the point of the question, "Why fuel cell and not battery vehicles?"

  Water Vapor Confirmed as Major Player in Climate Change

Comment: Expansion of parking opportunities at Agate Beach cannot be separated from the larger issue of managing recreational access to Iceberg Point. In proclaiming the San Juan Islands National Monument in 2013, President Obama focused on the need “to preserve the objects of scientific and historic interest on the lands of the San Juan Islands” i.e. rare plants and archaeological sites. Recreation is not identified as an objective, much less as a priority. How recreation can be squared with protection is a major theme of the planning process for the Monument, now in its third year. Yet the Interior Department has jumped the gun, promoting tourism at Iceberg Point and elsewhere in the Monument. Parking expansion is not just about safety and access to county land. It will foster access to Iceberg Point, before we have agreed on how much tourist traffic Iceberg Point can sustain. Let's finish the Monument management plan before we build more parking for visitors.

Comment: Cat: Re: your "commodity transport companies" and "tales from the litterbox." 

I'll go out on a limb and assume that you don't have any idea how ENB's (or what you call a "commodity transport company" stock has performed in oil bear markets. Right?
Well, since the early 1970's, there have been four times where the price of oil dropped 60% or more. Those are clearly bear markets for oil. How did ENB's stock do in those four bear markets? Well if you take ENB's share price from the day the price of oil peaked until the day it bottomed (average decline was 70%, range was 62% to 80% and average timeframe was 32 months), the return on ENB's stock was an average gain (note it was a gain, not a loss) over all of those times when the price of oil was decimated, was 66%. That is a return of approximately 21% per year---PLUS 21%/yr during oil bear markets.
Think whatever you like. Create your own opinion from wherever. But don't try to change or deny the facts.

Comment: Many have asked why did devout, practicing Catholics vote for Trump. First of all, I have never voted for a Democrat in my entire life. Born and raised a Republican and would not vote any differently. Secondly, I was a Jeb Bush supporter, and he lost. Trump was my only candidate. I would never have voted for Clinton. Was not even part of the thinking process.

Now, how do I reconcile that decision with my Catholic faith. I don't because the church is not monolithic. Any of us, whether Republican or Democrat, can twist and turn our partisan politics in any religious direction to justify our vote. I did not vote for Trump because of my faith; I did so because I am a conservative. Hilary was not.

I think that it is disingenuous to assume that good Catholics wear their religion on their sleeves when they vote. They don't. No one takes the faithful citizenship booklet to the voting booth; they hardly read it. Instead, we vote according to how we were raised and how we currently think.

Comment: Don't forget drugs, Brady.   20 years ago when we were trying to implement Welfare to Work in a very reluctant Knowles Administration we figured out that a welfare recipient with one dependent who used all the benefits available in Alaska had an effective income of about $39K/yr. plus the value of Medicaid.   That was about what we were paying entry-level supervisors and mid-level administrative and technical employees, and most of the WTW eligible couldn't meet the minimum qualifications for our lowest level entry jobs.    WTW didn't work very well here.   It is still true today; it is your own values that cause you to work in entry level/low-level jobs.   You're economically a Helluva lot better off on welfare and you don't have to get up and get out of your bathrobe.

Comment: The Irish Republic has handled this issue rather well.  They have a President, elected by popular vote but understood by all to fill a ceremonial position (but also be responsible for smoothing the way for the selection of a new Government that conforms to democratic, parliamentary conventions where former Government is defeated in the Irelands equivalent of our House of Commons or in a General Election) and otherwise stands apart from partisan politics.  

In short, the role parallels in all aspects that of Canada's Governor General but (a) it's filled by popular election, and (b) the link to the British Monarchy is severed.

Comment: DLNR amended its administrative rules to create a "safety zone" around Ahu O Laka (Kaneohe Bay sand bar). The rule, 13-256-73.13 (http://files.hawaii.gov/dlnr/dobor/rules/compiled/HAR256-Compiled.pdf), restricts anyone under the influence of alcohol or drugs from entering or remaining in the safety zone. The rule had to go through the rule making-process (which requires public comment and be approved by the BLNR). DOCARE is responsible for enforcing the rule. Creating a similar rule for Waikiki would be more more difficult to implement and enforce because it's a much larger area. With that said, it's ridiculous to be drinking while floating around in the ocean, especially with strong offshore winds. Where did these people grow up? Furthermore, when the fun is more about the alcohol and less about enjoying the ocean, it's not really a "recreational activity."

Comment: Hello Larry ... Your question affirms my point that once an observer has a category (e.g. "male") in mind, there are almost automatic limitations on the following observations. Two thoughts come to mind.  The first is that the physical distinctions are not always that easy to identify (hermaphrodites, for example). The second is that regardless of the physical "category" there are the psychological identifications (of the one being observed). Transgender people almost always describe that they knew this "psychological truth" early in life.

As scientific knowledge progresses very likely the categories become more "fine-tuned" - hopefully gradually closing in on what is "more true" of reality than was previously understood. The mores and laws of any social group/government always lag behind what is actually happening in a population. I would love to know what the laws of the US will be in 200 years. I bet people will think that some of our 2016 laws were strange and archaic.

A Vietnamese gentleman saw me looking out and said in English, "that is a very nice view" and I said, "Yes it is. The last time I saw this view was 45 years ago". He looked at me and said "you were in the American War?".  He, then asked to sit down with me.  Which I said sure and we had a 45 minute conversation.  You see, they have more than "one war" by which they define things.  We were just another domino, in-their-way, to independence.  Hola from sunny Costa Rica.

Comment: Apparently you can't refrain from picking at Sundt's piece, rather than addressing its substance, so let me dissect your own post.

_Ad hominem_ arguments attempt to reject a prior argument based on of some _irrelevant_ fact about the argument's author.

_"Sundt assumes 'they [Wolling and Duncan] nor most proponents of the plan have made any effort to learn and understand [the situation]' (argument from motives)"_

Sundt's claim is unrefuted and is not _ad hominem. It addresses the _credibility_ of Wolling and Duncan, which is highly relevant and would be permissible in a court of law.

_“and 'proponents are convinced they have the moral high ground' (we have a higher moral ground because we don’t claim the moral high ground)"_

You deceptively fail to include the whole sentence, which Sundt began: "But I admit great “fear” that conventional and uncritical thinking will prevail, because ..." This was not an _argument_, but rather an explanation of the author's feelings.

(continued)

Comment: It should be clear from the report, the supplementary reports, and the aftermath that this whole process is about each political party looking out for its own interests, not the interests of diverse Canadians. Noe of this would have happened if: (i) a citizens' assembly approach had been used, over at least 18 months, to carry out the research, truly listen to Canadians, and develop a consensus set of recommendations, taking into full account the changing nature of Canada over the next thirty years, (ii) all Canadian citizens had been well informed and educated about all of the issues, not just the issue of fairness and proportionality, (iii) a referendum had been held with clear questions and clear approval bars (% of eligible, and more than 60%), and (iv) then, and only then, a full discussion in Parliament leading to a decision. On this issue, politicians and political parties, the Minister, and the committee have absolutely failed all of us. We should be appalled and sad.

Comment: Larry,

While that confrontation in Congress was the first real opposition to Sen. Joe McCarthy, what he never recovered from was an expose done by CBS News correspondent Edward R. In his commentary about McCarthy, Murrow observed that Communism was "the great evil of our time" and that it was based on a web of lies. Comment: Kinda surprised that the reactions to your comment thus far have been so negative.

We have done this before with Kingston Pen.  The inmates there wouldn’t likely have lasted ten minutes in the general population of a maximum security institution.  I can’t really say whether we have something similar now….but would suspect so.

But the problem wouldn’t be totally solved.  When prisoners are on remand and immediately after sentencing, they stay in regional detention centres.  And they generally go to an institution like Millhaven for assessment once they enter the federal system.  

So even if we had an institution for kid killers and the rest of the flotsam that comprises the jailhouse basement,  those inmates would still be at risk.  And there are plenty who think they will earn jailhouse cred by picking on them.

Comment: I’d venture that the one thing you claim you know, you don’t really know at all.

The auto industry in Michigan did not collapse due to hourly wage and benefits for the union workers. There were several factors. When the unions formed, the auto companies reacted by decentralizing the manufacturing process, i.e. building two plants that produced exactly the same product, so if one union at one plant went on strike, the other plant was still producing a sellable product. A smart move.
Over time, other changes had an impact on the industry. New immigration laws, which reduced worker influx. Automation, reduced labor requirements. OPEC, increased cost of fuel. International competition, cheaper foreign cars hitting the market. All this further escalated the decentralization of the auto industry in Michigan. Manufacturers moved their plants to states that were cheaper in terms of land, taxes, regulation, labor, etc.

He's no smarter nor dumber than any other child.  Take a look at Ontario's math curricula, which was dumbed down my McGuinty.  That's the culprit.
Kids are capable, but they need good curricula, and competent teachers who are held accountable.  
I do not support public education.  I support charter schools and the voucher system.

Comment: I am an ex-military military member & have built from parts kits several AR-15 carbine rifles. There is recoil in an AR, but its very little pre single shot & muzzle rise.
Now dumping the magazine with rapid fire, will need you to have a stance & knowledge capable of dealing with the recoil/ muzzle rise.
Now on the parts the M-16 & AR-15 are different internally more than externally.
The bolt carrier, sear, hammer, hammer springs, trigger, trigger springs, safety selector are totally different in both rifles. Bushmaster 2016 Catalog shows a M-16, 3 round burst part set & states that you need to be an FFL or a Form 4 to buy.
Externally, the M-16 carbines have a 14.5" barrel while the AR-15 carbine is 16". NFA law passed around 1936, gave limits on what civilian shotgun & rifle barrel lengths could be & full auto weapons were illegal unless you had the license. So there is a license on certain guns, but not for all.

Comment: Currently yes,  the ice is has been increasing in the Antarctica overall and has been for years. But is this the smoking gun against climate change? Not quite. Antarctic sea ice is gaining because of many different reasons but the main ones are:

a) Ozone levels over Antarctica have dropped causing stratospheric cooling and increasing winds which lead to more areas of open water that can be frozen 
b) The Southern Ocean is freshening because of increased rain and snowfall as well as an increase in melt-water coming from the edges of Antarctica's land ice . Together, these change the composition of the different layers in the ocean there causing less mixing between warm and cold layers and thus less melted sea and coastal land ice. 

Also, while there has been an increase in sea ice, there has been a greater *decrease* in land ice.

The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has published a five-volume set of guidelines that all the countries now use, as part of the UN Framework Convention on climate change, for estimating emissions on all greenhouse gases and it does produce uniformity across countries.  The error margin depends on the country and on the greenhouse gas.  I think the interest is partly in carbon dioxide emitted from energy systems, and in that case, it really depends on how much a country invests in collecting energy statistics.  For countries like those in the EU or the US or Japan, my guess is that the error margin is something in the order of plus or minus 5%.  For those discharging smaller quantities of CO2, the error bars, I think can be as high as 20 to 25% and there are some very large countries – in China, we’ve actually published the estimate that they are maybe as large as 15 or 20

Comment: The key thing to watch may be the two open seats on the Federal Reserve Board. From Canada’s perspective, they may be more important than U.S. Supreme Court appointments.  If Trump appointed economists or business people closer to his world view, we may see an expedited rise in interest rates and quantitative de-easing. This would be a challenge for Canada, as one would have to follow the rate rises or have the dollar fall even further. Comment: I do not have any opinion about whether Dunn Hall should be renamed at the U of O or whether Dunn was an ongoing member/ leader of the Eugene KKK.  I do strongly object to Igl's assertion that "Support for Prohibition, not racism or anti-Catholicism, was probably the number 1 issue of the 1920's KKK".  That is a major distortion of history.  See the Oregon History Society's Oregon History Project: Proclamation Against the Ku Klux Klan, 1922 written by Governor Ben Olcott on 5/13/22. Governor Alcott lost the Nov 1922 election by 57% to 43% to the Klan backed Democratic candidate Walter Pierce.  In the same election an anti-Catholic initiative was approved by Oregon voters stipulating that attendance at parochial schools did not meet the requirement for school attendance.
Besides anti-Catholic bias there was a major bias against Jewish people (ie Klan members boycotted the Meier & Frank store as it was a "Jewish store"). To ignore all this context is a gross distortion of history.

Comment: For people interested in learning more about obesity and its effects on your health, I highly recommend reading the 2010 "Obesity and life expectancy" research paper that was published by the National Obesity Observatory in the United Kingdom.   This research used data from 57 studies done across Europe, as well as in the USA and Australia, involving over 900,000 patients suffering from obesity.

In this study, they discovered that BMI - Body Mass Index, was by far the strongest predictor of increased mortality.  And that as BMI increased, so did the mortality rate.  So much so that people who were morbidly obese, risked decreasing their life span as much as 10 years.

Comment: This is like a bad comedy.  Initially, Mufi said, "do we need it, can we afford it, can we maintain it?"  The answer must have been YES to all.  Rail was a 3B dollar project from Kapolei to UH-Manoa that was going to be built on time and on-budget according to Caldwell.  We were assured that the rail would mitigate the traffic woes from the west.  Then, we voted.  Well, here we are years later, cost is over 3x initial estimates, the "temporary" tax surcharge looking more and more permanent, the rail will NOT be going to UH-Manoa, or possibly even to Ala Moana, and experts say that it will NOT mitigate traffic, too.  So, what did we buy?  And what will we be continuing to pay for generations?  Years from now, our great-great grandchildren living on the mainland because of Hawaii's high cost of living will read about it being torn down because the rails were too rusty for the train and maintenance costs were too high and wonder why great-great grand dad/mom agreed to it.  Sorry kids!

Comment: "Today, immigrants are 1.5 times more likely than average Canadians to live in poverty, and twice as likely to earn less than $30,000 a year, after 15 years."

This is a sobering reality that's ignored in the first three-quarters of the column. Whatever the skills of new immigrants, recent arrivals simply aren't as successful as were their cohorts in previous generations. By some estimates, this is costing taxpayers $25 - $35 billion annually at present, and rising. Immigration used to be a nation building strategy, first to build an agrarian economy that required agricultural labour and later to sustain a growing industrial economy that required factory workers and tradesmen. But in a transitional post-industrial economy, the role of immigration is unclear. Now, it's seen more as an investment that, hopefully, will someday produce dividends on the billions being poured into supporting a lot of economically marginal migrants. It seems to me that this is a gigantic speculative gamble.

Comment: In the first place, there was no "Inquisition", there were many inquisitions.

It was common for people to petition to move their case from the state courts to the courts of the inquisitions because they were fairer.

A good book on the topic would be Rodney Stark's "Bearing False Witness: Debunking Centuries of Anti-Catholic History". He is a sociologist of religion.

He writes “The standard account of the Spanish Inquisition is mostly a pack of lies, invented and spread by English and Dutch propagandists in the sixteenth century during their wars with Spain, and repeated ever after by the malicious or misled historians.”

He does a splendid job of dismantling the "Hilter's Pope" and associated slurs, which today alone on this very blog I have read repeated by self-described Catholics.

Comment: My personal experiences with mental illness is that there are very, very few readily available resources (i.e. an appointment tomorrow) for people who are coping, managing, but on the edge. The system is overwhelmed just dealing with the extreme cases, so it almost becomes a necessity to have a crisis in order to get timely treatment. At that point the system kicks in full gear and from my experience is quite effective. We cannot afford as a society to have trained experts sitting around all day waiting for patients, but we are operating at the other extreme right now. I happen to live in a large rural area in Ontario. There are two/three psychiatrists at the regional hospital. That is it for a region of about 200,000+ people. Talk to the local GP's and they will, if they are brave enough to admit it, tell you they effectively are the first and in many cases only and last resort for medications for those that need it.  Change can do good. More money pumping up what we have is faster.

Comment: Glad to see you've dialed it back a notch, but you could go a notch further.

Google's service can be accessed from almost anywhere, but Google as an entity doesn't operate in almost every country in the world. It has a business presence in 50 countries- about 25% of the world's nations. Those are the only places it need concern itself about local laws- except when it doesn't.

Crime doesn't care about borders. In fact, borders are an advantage for criminals because they can use them to evade prosecution. Google is facilitating an alleged crime in this case. I doubt if they'd take such a laissez-faire approach if it was their stolen technology that was turning up in Google searches.

Google can eliminate the problematic material from its search results any time it wishes. It would be nice if a Canadian court didn't have to order them to do the right thing, to "not be evil." But it looks more like Google refuses to remove the material for no other reason than it thinks it can.

Let me explain, CA and NY matter.  All 50 states matter.  All 3,000+ counties matter.  Each vote matters.  But the way they matter is based on the system (the electoral college) that says, "hey candidate, if want to be president you need to make sure you have support across a broad swath of America.  This is because, as the guardian of democracy, I want to make sure that vast majority of America is represented.  Therefore, I give you a cap on how much a particular place will count in the electoral college.  Go above that fine, but you need minimum support everywhere."

Good day sir or madam, whichever the case may be.

Comment: No bed, no arrest, no tickets/citing for living in the parks.
No public shelter in Lane County, no constitutional authority to harass poor people who have no other place to go.
Provide such a shelter, fund it with a meals tax or from a dedicated lottery, then and only then a municipality has the right to force people to leave the public square. 
I am no constitutional scholar, but I so wish the principle would be brought to the Supreme Court to be tested...is it legal to arrest homeless people for the crime of not going anywhere when there is no place to go?
And yes, there are men and women who live on the streets, as a matter of choice,  who are not good citizens of the municipality and who should be forced to find another place. A city has a right to defend itself against those who would be disruptive and harmful. But there is no way to sort it out without a pubic shelter system.
Hugh Massengill, Eugene Oregon

Comment: My purpose was to disprove your assertion that it was a 'trickle' at first and that the most significant decline occurred during the papacy of St John Paul II. The statistics show that your assertion was incorrect, that the steeper decline occurred in the late sixties and the seventies and became much gentler over the next four decades. 
The Mass attendance figures for the UK show a sharp decline during WWII followed by a sharp increase up to the mid sixties. After that the decline followed the same pattern as in the USA.
As far as I am aware there has been no decline in the populations of either th UK or the USA since the war, the opposite in fact.
As I said above my aim was solely to show that the greatest exodus from the Church occurred during the seventies which the statistics bear out.

Comment: Seriously, Out, you must know that EVERYONE complains about industrial monoculture in the Midwest, not because of the products but because of the ecological impacts. 

You didn't choose a very good comparison to state your case, to say the least

The destruction by monoculture of the tallgrass prairies of the great plains--once THE most biodiverse region in North America--has severely diminished the planet's ability to sequester carbon. It's also caused problems with huge dead zone/algae blooms in the Gulf of Mexico and other assorted water pollution woes.

To fight global warming requires maximum biodiversity and the rewilding of forest lands and prairies to accomplish that. "Maximum tree production" won't help. Is it really widely argued that lumber production is an effective form of carbon sequestration? I understand the reasoning, sure enough, but the carbon cost of  logging and production and the impact of industrial logging on fires and biodiversity seem incalculable.

Comment: Some of this is correct, some is not.

You need a pilot certificate AND a medical in order to legally fly solo. It may be a student pilot certificate, private, commercial, or ATP. And you need at least a 3rd class medical. Medicals used to also serve as the student pilot certificate, and concurrently expired in 2 years or 5 years (for 3rd class medicals), depending upon your  age. 

Student pilot certificates must now be applied for separately, and, as in other certificates, never expire. They may be suspended or revoked through FAA enforcement actions, though. They are terminated by the issuance of a private or higher certificate.

"High Performance", "Complex", and "Tailwheel" are endorsements in your logbook, given by an instructor who is satisfied that you meet those requirements. "Multiengine" and "Floatplane" are formal ratings that you earn via an oral and practical test by an examiner.

There are no tests or endorsements for ski or aerobatic flying. Training is advisable tho.

Comment: David Knudson: Red-meat nonsense rhetoric & bumper-sticker racism are no substitute for conservative economic practices & financial intelligence in public finance. Budget cutting is the ONLY leg of the 3-legged Alaska Finance stool that the Legislature has taken any action on at all. much has already been cut, & more cuts will likely come over the next 1-2 years. But while “cuts-only” may suit YOUR interests, that path is  economic insanity & total fiscal recklessness for Alaska if we hope to still have a functioning State in 3 short years—-

A sensible, conservative action plan.

Comment: That column, from a politically conservative website, is the author's opinion, nothing more. His statement "the fundamental idea of Socialism is ... that morality is a matter entirely in the jurisdiction of mankind" is true of certain socialists, specifically the more doctrinaire Marxists, but is not the "fundamental idea" of socialism. Indeed, he admits as much in the next sentence, "This idea may not be expressly formulated in all socialist teaching". It is found in Marxist philosophy, but not in Marxist economics, which is a separate field. This sort of thing is why I keep saying that conservatives, as a rule, know little of actual socialism.

Comment: Adam Smith wrote that with the right glazing and heating it was possible to grow bananas in Edinburgh.
.
This largely sums up the adventures of governments in subsidising aerospace.
.
Some nations regard aerospace as strategic, and pour public funds into it for both vanity and military readiness.
.
Can, or should, Canada afford to play that game?
.
Despite the huge advantages Bombardier had when it acquired the DHC-8 facility in Downsview, it has had a long, tough go developing new designs.
.
On the other hand, without those subsidies, Bombardier quietly became the largest commuter rail supplier in the world.
.
Don't think those trains are high technology?
Don't think commuter rail is a huge sunrise industry?
Would it have been better to have invested the money in that success?
.
Governments
(a) are not Warren Buffett; and
(b) have a terrible history trying to pick winners in technology.
.
Is it really worth growing bananas in Edinburgh?
Or is there a better use for that money?

Comment: The last high tech engineering entry-level job I hired for offered 4 positions.  There were 160 applicants, but only 12 applicants were women, or ~8%.  We hired 1 women for one of the four positions, or ~25%, as her skills and experience stood out from the other applicants.  This is a big leap given the sample we were given to work with, but it was not possible to have a 50-50 split because only that woman out of the 12 met the qualifications.  If women want to work in high tech or want high paying jobs, then study, train, develop skills for, and apply for these jobs.  It's that simple.  There are no educational boundaries, no barriers to entry or advancement for women in high tech.  Complaints from society about a 'gender gap' are nonsensical.  The evidence shows that women, on average, simply choose not to work in fields that are the highest paying or that traditionally have been dominated by men.  In my experience, it's all on women to fix the gender gap.

Comment: Who paid for the $185,000 hip replacement? Not the insurance companies. We did. Does anyone believe a hip replacement should cost $185,000? Here are the costs as listed on the web for various countries. I checked with a few other sites and they agree to within 20%: 
On average, total hip replacements cost:
$6,757 in Spain
$7,685 in South Africa
$15,465 in New Zealand
$16,335 in the United Kingdom
$17,112 in Switzerland
$19,484 in Australia
$29,067 in the Unites States

Yet the story we're supposed to believe is that all the other civilized countries give you risky procedures and fake drugs. I agree, you will have to wait much longer in most countries. But can this explain the difference in cost?

Comment: Where to start, where to start. No, the corporate entity themselves aren't people. however the people who work there and who are respresented by them are people. It's human beings who have Constitutional rights, not objects, or things. 
So, if the ACLU, through an employee speaks on behalf of a client or clients about constitutional issues which only apply (or should only apply) to human beings, there's no problem. It's when a non-human legal construct - such as a corporation - is granted Constitutional rights i.e. Personhood, that the slippery slope begins, as it has with Citizens United. I mean if you think you're in equal Constitutional ground with, say, your corner grocery store, good for you.  But neither I nor decades of legal precedent agree with Citizens United, an activist ruling by a far right activist court.

Comment: Ignore what the industry-sponsored AHA doctors say; scientists say that not skipping breakfast may be bad for your heart.

The science is pointing to hyper-insulinemia and insulin resistance as the main drivers of cardiovascular disease. An effective means to avert this condition is to have postprandial insulin levels return to base-line before eating again. An effective means to do this is to have a 12-16 hour window in which one does not eat, which can be done by skipping breakfast. Indeed, regular fasting is a part of most traditional cultures that have persisted for millennia. Of course if one eats very badly in the remaining hours of the day and has other poor habits the benefit of a daily fast may be undermined, but the conclusions imposed on the associational data by the AHA are unscientific and the AHA's dietary recommendations have done nothing to improve health and have arguably worsened the type two diabetes epidemic.

Comment: That's such a false narrative. Japan *was* ready surrender on one condition: that the emperor was allowed to keep his symbolic position as head of state. In addition to Japan already having offered a total surrender with only one largely-symbolic condition, Japan also had no military capacity remaining and no longer posed a threat to America or any other nation in the region for that matter. There is absolutely no justification.

Comment: It's unusual that I say this about your posts, but I think this time you really blew it. Your point is good. It just doesn't hit the mark. What Obama's executive order did had little if anything to do with keeping guns out of the hands of the mentally ill. It put 75,000 people on the NICS's "no guns" list simply because they indicated to the Social Security Administration that they needed some kind of assistance with their finances. This could mean that they needed someone to take their check to the bank to deposit it or it could mean that they were mentally incapacitated to the extent that they could no longer handle their finances (and if addled to that degree, should probably not possess a gun). However, there was no way to determine the degree or type of impairment. Then, as has been pointed out, the order amounted to the deprivation of a Constitutional right without due process or even notification.
I think the order was just Obama's feel good effort to add to his legacy.

Comment: I think that in every article written about the rise in real estate prices ignores an important reason for the increased demand for housing and how it will lead a beneficial shift behavior. Demand for housing in cities has been driven partly by the out migration from rural communities and small towns across the country. Leaving economies struggling and a supply of cheap housing in these unfashionable places. Comment: Because human beings, like other primates, are hard-wired to expect a sexual division of labour.  Yes, in hunter-gatherer societies it's the males who went after the big game.  But even in those societies there are many roles that are sex-specific but have nothing to do with size or physical attributes.  The division of sex roles is often quite arbitrary.  With a few obvious exceptions, such as the hunting example you mentioned, it doesn’t really matter what role is assigned to which sex.  The important thing is that they're a binary opposition.  Think de Saussure, think Levi-Strauss.

I’d argue that the perverse attempt to steamroll over human nature is the cause of much mental illness today, particularly gender dysphoria and disorders of sexual attraction.

Comment: I get not liking the alternatives too much, but how do you reach the conclusion that the economy is running well here? The only major bright spot is real estate/construction, which has exploded to become 1/3 of GDP. It's the boom in this one sector that is making everything look "good" economically. But if you look at this "success" in any sort of detail, it sure doesn't look like a win if your goal is to build a sustainable economy that will prosper in the future. The economy is very de-diversified. The Lower Mainland has a growing net loss of people under the age of 45, with 60%+ people reporting a desire to leave the region (which comprises over half the province's population). Business and government leaders in Vancouver, and now Victoria are reporting significant issues attracting and retaining talent. These sorts of problems are not the byproducts of a well run economy. They are what happens when you burn the future to shine today.

"When it comes to fluoridation research, even the best studies are not high quality. Although this was already well-established, it doesn't seem to be well-known.  ...

...
But most scientists interviewed for this article don’t necessarily think fluoridation’s uncertain benefits justify its continuation without more stringent evidence, and argue for more research into the matter.
